Joyless I seek the solitary scene,</br>Where dusky Contemplation veils the scene,</br>The dark retreat (of leafless branches made)</br>Where sick'ning sorrow wets the yellow'd green.
The darksome ruins of some sacred cell,</br>Where erst the sons of Superstition trod,</br>Tott'ring upon the mossy meadow, tell</br>We better know, but less adore, our God.
Now, as I mournful tread the gloomy cave,</br>Thro' the wide window (once with myst'ries dight)</br>The distant forest, and the dark'ned wave</br>Of the swol'n Avon ravishes my sight.
But see, the thick'ning veil of evening drawn,</br>The azure changes to a sabled blue,</br>The rap'tring prospects fly the less'ning lawn,</br>And nature seems to mourn the dying view.
Self-frighted Fear creeps silent thro' the gloom,</br>Starts at the rustling leaf, and rolls his eyes;</br>Aghast with horror, when he views the tomb,</br>With ev'ry torment of a Hell, he hies—
The bubbling brooks in plaintive murmurs roll,</br>The bird of Omen with incessant scream,</br>To melancholy thoughts awakes the soul,</br>And lulls the mind to Contemplation's dream.
A dreary stillness brood o'er all the vale,</br>The clouded Moon emits a feeble glare;</br>Joyless I seek the darkling hill and dale,</br>Where'er I wander Sorrow still is there.</br>
